item.title: Paropsisterna nigerrima
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This dark beetle is Paropsisterna nigerrima var. picta. The structure is identical to the common striped form but the color pattern is different. The important srtuctural feature to note for ID is the fine striae (puncturation lines) along the elytra. Sadly, the color patterns are no help. The third variety (nigerrima nigerrima) is entirely black. I suspect that at least two more variations occur that are not recorded in the MOV collection. One is entirely light and dark banded, the other is from NSW and has a different red spot pattern.

item.title: Paropsisterna morio
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is always dark. Close inspection will reveal that it comes in at least two varieties, one entirely black. The second variety has subtle red lines on the elytra. Another (rare) has brown elytra. This beetle is common and widespread along the east coast including Tasmania. It always has very fine and virtually imperceptible striae puncturations. It has strong foveae on the pronotum (dimples in its cheeks). These are crepuscular and found most easily under bark of candlebark/manna gum types which offer large spaces for them to hide.

item.title: Paropsisterna nigerrima
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A dark and variable beetle. This variation is "alternata" with alternate interstices containing red stripes. The striae bear lines of fine puncturations in good alignment. Easily confused with Paropsisterna morio which has extremely fine to almost non existent striae punctiurations. These beetles are crepuscular, at least in Victoria and retire under bark during daylight hours.

item.title: Peltoschema basicollis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This species is Peltoschema basicollis. This orange beetle with black spots is clearly a coccinellidae mimic. These beetles are monophagous, obligate feeders on Acacia buxifolia and the beetles were restricted to a small stand of this acacia in a small section of the park. These are easily and commonly mistaken for ladybirds but feature a black suture. There are at least three species of Peltoschema in a complex of ladybird mimic species.

item.title: Acacia buxifolia subsp. buxifolia
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small Acacia with short pale phyllodes.

item.title: Calomela acaciae
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A green and white striped acacia leaf beetle.

item.title: Acacia wilhelmiana
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small pale Acacia

item.title: Isopeda montana
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A pale grey huntsman, less common in this habitat.

item.title: Delena cancerides
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A common timid spider with dark leg tips.

item.title: Nephila edulis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Egg sac of orb spider

item.title: Nephila edulis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A large female orb spider

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A green spined hemipteran bug

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: I do not know this species of Paropsisterna. This leaf beetle is quite common and I have seen it in many parts of Victoria.

item.title: Paropsisterna variicollis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A very common leaf beetle with rows of beading or marbling along the striae of the elytra. The body and legs are always black. The insect is sometimes brown. green, red, orange, yellow or entirely black. The pronotum is typically patterned with a clear patch either side of the centre line.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small brown crab spider found under bark.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A wingless cockroach might be female or nymphal.

item.title: Laxta granicollis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A handsome winged (male) cockroach.

item.title: Drymaplaneta communis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A glossy wingless native cockroach with lateral white stripes.

item.title: Calolampra spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A slim winged cockroach

item.title: Trachymela sloanei
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A brown convex beetle with black bumbs ober the elytra.

item.title: Reduviidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A very slim member of the assassin bug group.

item.title: Reduviidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A tiny true bug with furry legs and antennae. Found with an adult, this unwinged specimen is a nymph.

item.title: Nezara viridula
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This common green bug can sometimes become an agricultural pest.

item.title: Reduviidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small true bug (Reduvidae?) with hairy legs and antemmae.

item.title: Tandanus tandanus
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The skeleton of a fish with a very flat head and thickly set tail. My guess is a catfish. Tandanus tandanus? Would someone like to confirm?

item.title: Morethia boulengeri
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small skink

item.title: Christinus marmoratus
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A thick tailed gecko with pretty orange blotches along its back. The marbled gecko is only one species that we are likely to see and there were several found.

item.title: Geoscaptus spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is a ground beetle (Carabidae) The genus s Geoscaptus A large shiny black beetle is easily confused with a stag beetle or a bess beetle.

item.title: Curculionoidea spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A colorful weevil with tufts of fur.

item.title: Nyctemera amicus
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The genus is Nyctemera. A black and white moth common through out Australia and Asia. Black and white... a magpie of course.

item.title: Dolophones spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Genus is Dolophones sp. A cryptic type of orb spider resembling the knot of a twig.

item.title: Reduviidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: An assassin bug

item.title: Lychas marmoreus
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Lychas: marmoreus Little marbled scorpions with their diagnostic secondary stinger are hibernating communally under the bark of river redgums. They are considered to be ground dwellers but there were many found in trees today.

item.title: Pseudoscorpiones spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A tiny tailless pseudoscorpion.

item.title: Peltoschema hamadryas
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small leaf beetle found in numbers on a broad leafed acacia. They seem to hide in the tiny flower buds.

item.title: Trachymela spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A new and unknown species of Trachymela

item.title: Peltoschema maculiventris
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Peltoschema maculoventris. It is more heavily marked than Peltoschema hamadryas and generally the black markings are entirely joined

item.title: Peltoschema tetraspilota
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Peltoschema tetraspilota is a four spotted leaf beetle found quite scarcely on acacia. I have found it only on silver wattle.

item.title: Peltoschema hamadryas
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle was found on silver wattle. The patterns are quite variable. I do not think it occurs in the same large numbers as the fireblight beetle P. orphana. The larva is yellow and appears in another spotting. A yellow larva is certainly a flower feeder.

item.title: Peltoschema perplexa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Peltoschema perplexa in its pale form. Many leaf beetles can appear in a green form or a yellow form or anywhere in between. For the purposes of identification, the markings on the elytra are most reliable.

item.title: Peltoschema orphana
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Peltoschema orphana is the most common leaf beetle found on Acacia, usually silver wattle. Commonly called the fireblight beetle it can cause devastation to silver wattle populations and even kill trees by defoliation. This versatile little beast is polyphagus and was feeding, with several others, and their larvae, on Eucalyptus which is uncommon but has been recorded before.

item.title: Peltoschema perplexa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Peltoschema perplexa. I have determined this by comparison of its consistent pattern with the museum of Victoria collection. This beetle seems to be scarce and I have seen it only twice. Peltoschema is a genus of Acacia feeders and this one seems to occur on the small leafed wattle illustrated. Maybe someone knows the species. Christmas Hills has a population of these wattles and we found many beetles that day

item.title: Peltoschema pandora
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Peltoschema pandora. Small, scarce and illustrated already on ALA website.

item.title: Peltoschema oceanica
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This leaf beetle is vegetarian but easily mistaken for its mimicry model, the carnivorous spotted ladybird beetle. This one is sometimes mis-identified in photographic images and pinned collections. Leaf beetles have long antennae and ladybirds are very short and slightly knobbed in that department. This beetle has four pronotal spots (usually) and once you notice this, you will hardly be fooled by this devious copycat beetle.

item.title: Peltoschema suturalis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The larvae of Peltoschema suturalis feed on broad leafed Acacia. These were found on Golden Wattle.

item.title: Paropsisterna crocata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna crocata This pale green beetle stayed for two photos and was gone. The one I saw last year flew away before I could lift my camera. This uncommon beetle occurs in a range of pale and subtle colors. Kilsyth; Chirnside Park and Eltham North; http://user-generated-content.natureshare.org.au/observations/photos/x1024/53b7f028e35eb16e5a00003f.JPG?1404563553

item.title: Paropsisterna crocata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna crocata. The pale green or peachy tan (in this case) monotone color on this large and handsome beetle is very distinctive. It is certainly among the largest of all Paropsisterna and seldom encountered. This has been recorded in Canberra also. See another in Eltham North; http://user-generated-content.natureshare.org.au/observations/photos/x1024/53b7f028e35eb16e5a00003f.JPG?1404563553

item.title: Curculionoidea spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Psapharus ruficornis A broad nosed beetle. This was identified for me on bowerbird but mine seems to be the only image available online for this species and nothing for comparison. .

item.title: Paropsisterna nucea
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna nucea is a common nitid (glossy) honey-brown leaf beetle. It does occur in a pale form and might have black markings on the pronotum. I have seen these at Mt Donna Buang, Kinglake, Eildon, Licola.

item.title: Paropsisterna nucea
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This specimen is a pale form of P. nucea which is more commonly a honey-brown color with lighter lateral margins.

item.title: Paropsisterna pictipes
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This pale beetle is a variation of the usual color of pale green and pink/red.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A colorful beetle with variable colours. I do not know the species for this specimen.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is possibly Paropsisterna decolorate. The elytral patterns differ somewhat and I can determine if this is differeny .

item.title: Paropsisterna m-fuscum
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna m-fuscum is a small beetle with a variable brown and blue/grey pattern on the elytra. A light flare often occurs at the base of the elytra. This species is sometimes a pest to eucalyptus plantations, particularly where they have been introduced into other countries.

item.title: Paropsis spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsis but undetermined.

item.title: Paropsis roseola
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsis roseola. This beetle is scarce and appears to occur in the Western deserts and further west to Perth. This beetle is identified by and named for its pink pronotum.

item.title: Dicranosterna immaculata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The distinctive larva of the acacia leaf beetle Dicranosterna immaculata.

item.title: Dicranosterna immaculata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A dark lead beetle with red skirt , head and suture. The larva is quite distinct and illustrated also.

item.title: Nambouria spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The parasitic wasp called Nambouria xanthops has formed this rooster comb gall. http://www.nzffa.org.nz/farm-forestry-model/the-essentials/forest-health-pests-and-diseases/Pests/Nambouria-xanthops

item.title: Apiomorpha spp., Apiomorpha urnalis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Apiomorpha urnalis is a woody gall produced by a parasitic hemipteran. The female inside the large gall remains physically underdeveloped and never independent of her host plant. The dissection shows the larviform adult female.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A tree laden with pendulose galls over more than 75% of its leaves. These are produced by a small scale insect (hemipteran). A busy wasp was taking full advantage by laying eggs into the deep gall chambers.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A stem gall produced by small wasps. These have been dissected to reveal the orange pupae and black wasps with elaborate antennae.

item.title: Unidentified
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: red galls like a bunch of tiny grapes along the mid-vein of a eucalyptus leafleaf

item.title: Fergusonina spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: These green grape galls are possibly produced by a parasitic fly in the Fergusonina genus. http://www.bowerbird.org.au/observations/2665

item.title: Chalcidoidea spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Galls are produced by Chalcidoidea wasps which are tiny black wasps with elaborate antennae.

item.title: Fergusonina spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This fly is Fergusonina spp. A small parasitic fly lays eggs while the leaves are still in bud. The pupae were collected and flies emerged in a few days.

item.title: Paropsisterna lignea
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This variable species is Paropsisterna lignea. It may have three dots on the pronotum and be strongly lined or entirely unlined elytra. It seems to be common in alpine habitats. There are interstitial puncturations (pitting between the rows of grooves) of random positioning but of equal size as the striae puncturations. (see close-up.)

item.title: Paropsisterna agricola
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna agricola occasionally shows off with a bright red skirt.

item.title: Paropsisterna agricola
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is named Paropsisterna agricola. It is common in Tasmania it can become an agricultural pest. The pale skirt can be bright red in some specimens. This species is determined by the black markings on the pronotum and the elytra with some flaring at the base.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna sp. This bright green beetle has variable red on the shoulders and sometimes covering the entire elytra. There is some red across the head and sometimes extending through the pronotum. Seen in Wonga Park, Glenburn and Eildon. Also in Tasmania. I have, on suggestion removed the P. laesa title as this beetle has striae puncturations in very regular lines and laesa is very irregular in its pattern as seen in the pinned specimen of laesa.

item.title: Calomela maculicollis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Calomela maculicollis. A widespread species of acacia leaf beetle identified by being broad and having three dots on the pronotum. There are sensory bristles on the corners of the pronotum and these can be folded away when not needed. They are very hard to see but are the determining feature for identifying the Calomela genus.

item.title: Calomela satelles
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Calomela satelles is an acacia leaf beetle. Calomela specialize on Acacia. They are small elongate and often orange or green.

item.title: Trachymela spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A large leaf beetle with red base color and black marks on the elytra.

item.title: Trachymela rugosa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Trachymela rugosa. A warty leaf beetle with meandering lines forming a complex pattern over the elytra. There remain two spots uncovered on the shoulders of the elytra forming two dots.

item.title: Trachymela spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Trachymela spp. A small leaf beetle with warty outgrowths on its elytra.

item.title: Trachymela sloanei
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Trachymela spp. A black beetle with neat rows of tubercles and a fine coating of white powder.

item.title: Trachymela spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small undetermined species of Trachymela

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is another Paropsisterna from the interlita group. I am not sure yet how they fit together and which species is which. This appears to be diurnal. I saw this also at Aberfeldy.

item.title: Paropsisterna intacta
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Paropsisterna intacta. A very rotund and large leaf beetle found under bark. I have seen these a dozen times and they are considered common. I have never seen them except under bark. They seem to prefer smooth (white) barked eucalyptus with large leaves.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna spp. It belongs in the interlita group but not sure the species. It looks like one that Russel Best has photographed in his lawn. http://natureshare.org.au/observations/53b3985ae35eb12984010d2c?species=Paropsisterna+spp.&tag= It is related to Paropsisterna intacta, an under bark nocturnal species. It features foveae (small dimples) in the sides of the pronotum, emphasized in this case by a black dot. I have seen this only once before at Taggerty on a small shrub. Found on a messmate eucalyptus. Seems to be diurnal

item.title: Paropsisterna decolorata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This colorful beetle is very variable. There is a pattern on the pronotum which contains the impression of a 'u' or horseshoe. There is often flaring from the base of the elytra which can make bright patterns. The white markings along the striae are larger and stronger than for variicollis.

item.title: Paropsisterna decolorata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna decolorata and shows a more common variety with strong white beading, lines and 'u' pattern on the pronotum and flaring from the base of the elytra.

item.title: Paropsisterna variicollis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A very common leaf beetle with rows of beading or marbling along the striae of the elytra. The body and legs are always black. The insect is sometimes brown. green, red, orange, yellow or entirely black. The pronotum is typically patterned with a clear patch either side of the centre line.

item.title: Peltoschema spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is from the polyphagus genus Peltoschema. This entirely green beetle is found on Lillypilly.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: I have no ID to offer for this species. It has definite similarities with P. atalanta which is mottled red but with the same black regions and found in the same location. I have seen this only once

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is small and green with a somewhat constant pattern of red zone along the elytra usually laterally and usually leaving a green stripe dorsally. The pronotum is green and usually unmarked or weakly marked with white patterns. I suspect this is might be P. obovata but lack confidence in this designation.

item.title: Paropsisterna pictipes
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This species looks like Paropsis but is Paropsisterna pictipes, A pale green leaf beetle with pink trim along the edges of the elytra and suture. The puncturations are strong and random and with no indication of striae, as might be expected for paropsis. Seen once only. Montane.

item.title: Paropsisterna erudita
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Paropsis erudita. It is a highly nitid (glossy) species found under bark of smooth barked eucalyptus spp. such as manna gum. This is the more scarce of the nocturnal leaf beetles in my experience and found only twice. Also seen at Wonga Park (Mt Lofty) and Healesville. It lacks striae grooves and puncturation is very fine. There are two very smart looking red diagonal lines on the combined elytra in the form of a chevron.

item.title: Paropsisterna morio
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Paropsisterna morio. It was found under bark of manna gum. It is entirely black sometimes with brown or lighter lines in the interstices (spaces between the striae). The elytra are highly nitid (glossy) and striae almost entirely lacking grooves. This beetle is variable in size but often large and elongate and very convex. I have seen one with a red neck (back of head) and assume it to be morio. I have not seen these except under bark. They are nocturnal and feed on large leaved eucalyptus such as manna gum. These glossy, black, nocturnal beetles feature foveau (large dints) on the pronotum, one on each side and this species also has a large crease in the elytral base directly behind these foveau. Paropsisterna morio is widespread from Tasmania to Queensland.

item.title: Paropsisterna beata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Paropsisterna beata. It is a highly nitid (glossy) species and lacking striae grooves. The combined elytra have six orange dots. The orange edge of the elytra and pronotum is important to note for ID purpose to avoid possible confusion with other similar species. Several specimens were found communally under a smooth barked Eucalyptus sp. which looks similar to a manna gum. This is a nocturnal species in Victoria but also occurs in northern states and appears to be diurnal there. I have never seen it except under bark. I have observed this species also in Mt Lofty (Wonga Park, Vic), Frankston, Croydon and the Basin.

item.title: Paropsisterna lineata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna lineata, a mostly black and highly nitid (glossy) beetle with a few consistent yellow lines along the striae. This is a nocturnal species and found in the daytime hiding in the gaps in stringy-bark bark. I have not found it on other species of eucalyptus. I have not found it except under bark. Also seen in Croydon, Ferntree Gully, the Basin and Tasmania.

item.title: Heteroptera spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: I am not sure of this Identification. A green shield bug perched on eucalyptus.

item.title: Heteroptera spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Not sure if this ID. A green spined hemipteran bug.

item.title: Symphyta spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A large wasp perched on a eucalyptus sapling.

item.title: Perga spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Steelblue Sawfly. Is this affinis or dorsalis??? A large hymenoptera perched in a eucalyptus.

item.title: Diphucrania spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is a Diphucrania sp. It feeds on Acacia foliage rather than nectar of flowers. This uncommon species has white spots on a purple elytra. The elytra are finely haired. The head and pronotum is sometimes green, as in this example.

item.title: Diphucrania spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is a Diphucrania species. A large green jewel beetle on foliage of black wattle. This species feeds on foliage rather than flowers. I saw three today, the other two were not as brightly colored (more green than purple) and might represent a different gender.

item.title: Castiarina sexguttata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Castiarina sexguttata, a small yellow jewel beetle with six or four or two or no green dots on the elytra.

item.title: Castiarina bifasciata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Castiarina bifasciata, a blue jewel beetle with two transverse yellow stripes.

item.title: 56 ids
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Species list for collection.

item.title: Paropsis variolosa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsis variolosa. This large leaf beetle is widespread across thew Australian mainland. It is red or brown with mottles white specks. I have also seen it at Taggerty and Sydney.

item.title: Paropsis marmorea
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsis marmorea is tricky to identify. It is defined by the positioning of the three main blotches on each elytra. These three marks should be compared with the similar Paropsis geographica. To avoid confusing these two beetles, imagine a triangle joining the tree main blotches on each elytra. The line through the top two blotches runs parallel to the suture and the lateral margin of the elytra almost exactly halfway between them.

item.title: Paropsis aegrota
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is called Paropsis geographic aegrota. The smaller dots are very variable and hardly considered in the determination of ID. The macula on the pronotum are large and open compared with geographica and colorata.

item.title: Paropsis minor
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsis minor is a small beetle with bright transverse banding of alternating black white and red. This tiny leaf beetle was found on tea tree. Many beetles benefit from good camouflage but this unexpectedly bright species seems oblivious to those supposed advantages.

item.title: Paropsis maculata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This bright species is Paropsis maculata. It is red with bright yellow spots, in particular two large spots behind the centre line of the beetle is very consistent. This was seen twice, the second tome in Moondarra NP. but it is more common in the northern states of NSW and Queensland. Maculata translated from Latin to 'spotted' and Paropsis means 'dish'.

item.title: Paropsis charybdis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is a color variation of the variable Paropsis charybdis. It is a large beetle usually with stronger bands and red along the cheeks and the skirt.

item.title: Paropsis augusta
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is the montane Paropsis augusta. It is the largest species of leaf beetle that I am familiar with. The color can vary from red to yellow. The black scutellum is consistent in this species.

item.title: Paropsis aegrota
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsis aegrota. This leaf beetle feeds on Eucalyptus leaves. It is a large leaf beetle with several white warty blotches on each elytra. The large dot positions are improtant for identification and the smaller ones are variable.

item.title: Micropezidae spp., Sparassidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small huntsman spider feasting on a stilt legged fly.

item.title: Melobasis spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Melobasis sp. A small green Jewel beetle found on foliage of eucalyptus.

item.title: Paropsis charybdis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsis charybdis. This beetle is marble white with complex red and brown patterns. This is a widespread and very variable beetle.

item.title: Dicranosterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Dicranostera spp. A honey brown beetle with pitted elytra and pronotum feeding on blackwood acacia.

item.title: Paropsisterna brunnea
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna brunnei, a brown leaf beetle with very smooth elytra and a black head. They usually have faint pinstripe lines along the elytra. This particular specimen is without the usual lines.

item.title: Paropsis aspera
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Paropsis aspera, a brown leaf beetle with the markings of an 'x' on the combined elytra. This beetle feeds on Eucalyptus as most other species also do but is anomalous as it does not fit easily into this genus.

item.title: Paropsisterna spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: I have no identification suggestion for this beetle. A purple leaf beetle with yellow margins extending most of the way into the suture.

item.title: Paropsisterna inspersa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is a small yellow leaf beetle which seems similar to Paropsisterna variicollis. The elytral striae have a series of puncturations each with a small black dot. These were only seen in a single location. This beetle is illustrated on PaDIL from where I have derived the identification. http://bie.ala.org.au/species/Paropsisterna+inspersa#tab_gallery

item.title: Paropsis intermedia
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A lightly mottled leaf beetle on manna gum foliage.

item.title: Trachymela rugosa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Trachymela are gnarled and highly textured beetles in brown colors. They are sometimes referred to as 'gumnut' leaf beetles on the presumption that they might mimic gumnuts. This beetle has sinuous ridges meandering over the elytra and with a small black dot near the forward half of the elytra.

item.title: Paropsisterna hectica
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is the typical alpine Paropsisterna hectica. The elytra are bright green and without much variation. The beetle is locally quite common and appears to be limited to stands of snow gum.

item.title: Paropsisterna atalanta
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is Paropsisterna atalanta. A rotund and mottled leaf beetle with its widest part towards the rear. This beetle was found on Eucalyptus. It is variable beetle and this example demonstrates the black marks that are usually present on the apex of the elytra and also at the base (forward) near the suture (centre line of the elytra). I have seen this beetle also at Frazer NP (Eildon) and Anglesea.

item.title: Calomela ioptera
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: An orange acacia leaf beetle - Calomela ioptera.

item.title: Paropsisterna hectica
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna hectica. A golden/green leaf beetle, sometimes with a red pigment extending from the base of the elytra. This species occurs from NSW to Victoria. A Tasmanian species is golden, rather than green and called Paropsisterna aurea. The Tasmanian beetle is still considered a different species but they are quite identical to this golden one and probably all belong to Paropsisterna hectica and will become synonomized in due course. This is found on Snow Gum (White Sallee). Also found in Licola.

item.title: Paropsisterna hectica
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna hectica. A golden/green leaf beetle, sometimes with a red pigment extending from the base of the elytra. This species occurs from NSW to Victoria. A Tasmanian species is golden, rather than green and called Paropsisterna aurea. The Tasmanian beetle is still considered a different species but they are quite identical to this golden one and probably all belong to Paropsisterna hectica and will become synonomized in due course. This is found on Snow Gum (White Sallee). Also found in Licola but they are green, not golden and the red flare was not noticed to occur in that population.

item.title: Paropsisterna hectica
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A golden/green leaf beetle, sometimes with a red pigment extending from the base of the elytra. This species occurs from NSW to Victoria. A Tasmanian species is golden, rather than green and called Paropsisterna aurea. The Tasmanian beetle is still considered a different species but they are quite identical to this golden one and probably all belong to Paropsisterna hectica and will become synonomized in due course. This is found on Snow Gum (White Sallee). Also found in Licola.

item.title: Paropsisterna nobilitata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The last of the tree gold and red leaf beetles with second pair of yellow blotched elongated and extending backwards and in no way outwards. This is the only species in Tasmania. It is most commonly found in Gippsland in my observation.

item.title: Paropsisterna atalanta
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Paropsisterna atalanta. A rotund and mottled leaf beetle feeding on Eucalyptus in the Anglesea heathland. I have seen this in Gisborne and Eildon. It is variable with black marks on the elytra at the base or the apex.

item.title: Paropsisterna semifumata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Paropsisterna semifumata. This small beetle is a riparian species and feeds only on white Callistemon spp.? growing in creeks and rivers along the eastern coast of Australia up to Brisbane. I've seen it both times that I've looked at this reserve but its probably common enough along Jacksons Creek wherever you find Callistemon. Semi + fumata translates in Latin to half + smokey.

item.title: Paropsisterna annularis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This beetle is uniquely lacking any of the normal red pigmentation. It was found nearby a normally colored specimen which is my previous observation. The patterning of the elytra with a ring of six small marks on the apical half of the elytra is completely consistent for Paropsisterna annulus.

item.title: Paropsisterna annularis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small bright leaf beetle with a complex pattern of yellow dots on a usually red background.

item.title: Paropsisterna gloriosa
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: A small but delightfully colored leaf beetle with yellow markings on red elytra.

item.title: Acacia howittii
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Small loose single flowers and small broad phyllodes (leaves).

item.title: Acacia buxifolia subsp. buxifolia
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Golden yellow flowers in August. Small racemes of 5 - 8 flowers. Small spider eating a hoverfly.

item.title: Apiomorpha spp., Eriococcidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This gall forming scale bug (Apiomorpha munita, family = Eriococcidae) produces a chemical stimulant causing the plant to grow a protective cage. The smaller posterior structures are (empty) male galls. The dissection shows the adult female prisoner with reduced wings, legs, antennae etc.

item.title: Reduviidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Wingless assassin bug, possibly Peirates sp.

item.title: Peltoschema suturalis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Peltoschema suturalis. This acacia leaf beetle seems to prefer broad leaf acacia and was found on Golden Wattle. This is the largest Peltoschema species that I am aware of. The name derives from the red line extending the length of the elytral suture. The species is not always green but can be yellow, as is also the case for P. orphana (fireblight beetle) and several similar species. .

item.title: Amanita phalloides
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Amanita phalloides, the Death Cap Mushroom. It was found in a suburban park and is not rare. This is responsible for two fatal meals in Victoria in 2012. Amanita have a universal veil (often leaving remnant patches on the cap)and a skirt on the

item.title: Schizophyllum commune
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This is Schizophyllum, a toxic species. Also called the Split Gill Fungus, it has no stipe(stem) gills are paired and the pileus (cap) is dry.

item.title: Cyathus novae-zeelandiae
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This species is Cyathus novaezelandiae. The Birds Nest Fungus has small spore packets in the 'nest' that are dispersed when a raindrop hits a 'bulls-eye'.

item.title: Lactarius deliciosus
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Lactarius deliciosus is the safron milk cap found under pine trees and according to its latin name is quite edible.

item.title: Amanita muscaria
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Amanita muscaria is the Fly Agaric. This best known mushroom is hallucinogenic but tastes too nauseating and is too toxic to be eaten. From the northern hemisphere, it grows from the roots of exotic trees including oak.

item.title: Chrysomelidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Leaf beetle eggs are laid in characteristic arrangements that differ for each species.

item.title: Paropsis pictipennis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This spotty leaf beetle is called Procrisina pictipennis and is rather scarce.

item.title: Lema bilineata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: Tobacco slug beetle (Lema bilineata) Found feeding on Brassica (canola)weeds growing in Fairfield.

item.title: Paropsis atomaria
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This tortoise leaf beetle (Paropsis atomaria) with its red skirt, is a more colorful variation of this species.

item.title: Paropsisterna intacta
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This leaf beetle is Paropsisterna intacta and has a pair of spare eyes on its thorax.

item.title: Paropsis atomaria
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This common Tortoise Leaf Beetle (Paropsis atomaria)gets its name from a reptile that can also completely withdraw its feet into (under) its shell. Antennae too.

item.title: Lycidae spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This Long Nosed Lycid Beetle (AKA Net winged beetle)is the model species for several mimics. Its bad taste discourages predators.

item.title: Pteropus poliocephalus
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This colony represents 50 000 bats that roost daily in the tall eucalyptus trees. There are 100 000 grey headed flying fox bats in Melbourne.

item.title: Scutiphora pedicellata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This half grown bug is a shield backed bug, it will look like Scutiphora pedicellata but the species is undetermined.

item.title: Doratifera vulnerans
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This 'saddleback' caterpillar is the Mottled Cupmoth (Doratifera vulnerans)and grows a hard woody (cup) pupal case and emerges as a delicately patterned brown moth.

item.title: Doratifera quadriguttata
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This eccentric moth larva has stinging bristles to discourage predators.

item.title: Doratifera vulnerans
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: The mottled cupmoth (Doratifera vulnerans)is named for its distinctive pupa. The second image is the larva spinning its cocoon.

item.title: Paropsisterna variicollis
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This tortoise leaf beetle (Chrysophtharta variicollis)is very common most summers with their groups of larvae chewing thorough fresh gum leaves and sometimes causing considerable damage.

item.title: Opodiphthera eucalypti
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This spectacular bright green caterpillar is the late instar larva and heavily infested with the eggs of a parasitic fly or wasp.

item.title: Junonia villida calybe
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This Meadow Argus is an aberration and has the posterior ocelli (eyespot) missing on the right hindwing.

item.title: Eupoecila australasiae
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This Fiddler beetle was found as one of nine pupal cases under the bark of a dead (tulip)tree. Eight beetles emerged (only the photographed larva didn't survive).

item.title: Xylonichus spp.
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This green beetle with pitted rows along its elytra was clinging desperately on a Ghania (swordgrass) blade.

item.title: Castiarina erythroptera
item.dc:creator: martinl
item.description: This red jewel beetle (Buprestidae) with deeply ribbed elytra is a mimic of the net winged lycid beetle.
